Efficient and recyclable catalysts based on simple chiral N 1-alkyl, N 2-arylmethyl diamines in the Cu-catalyzed asymmetric Henry reactions Fei Liu a Shaohua Gou a b ⁎ Lei Li a Peisheng Yan a Chunhong Zhao a a Pharmaceutical Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China Pharmaceutical Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University Nanjing 211189 China b Jiangsu Province Hi-Tech Key Laboratory for Bio-Medical Research, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China Jiangsu Province Hi-Tech Key Laboratory for Bio-Medical Research, Southeast University Nanjing 211189 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Pharmaceutical Research Center, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China. Tel.: +86 25 83272381; fax: +86 25 83272381. Graphical abstract A class of (1R,2R)-N 1-alkyl, N 2-(4-chlorobenzyl)cyclohexane-1,2-diamines (4) were designed and synthesized. They were used to form the corresponding copper(II) complexes, 4-Cu(OAc)2, as chiral catalysts in the asymmetric Henry reaction of benzaldehyde and nitromethane, in which the desired product was obtained with a good yield (up to 99%) and up to 96% ee. The optimized catalyst, 4g-Cu(OAc)2, was also found efficient in the asymmetric Henry reaction between different aldehydes (aromatic aldehydes or aliphatic aldehydes) and nitromethane. Upon scaling up to gram quantities, the β-nitroalcohol was obtained in good yield (91%) with excellent selectivities (93% ee). The recycled catalyst, 4g-Cu(OAc)2, worked well up to three catalytic runs with marginal loss in yield and the enantioselectivity of the product was retained. It is believed that this procedure provides an opportunity to facilely synthesize large amounts of enantiomerically enriched β-nitroalcohol. A possible catalytic transition state for the asymmetric Henry reactions with our catalyst was suggested. Keywords Asymmetric catalysis Henry reaction Copper Chiral diamine β-Nitroalcohol 1 Introduction The asymmetric Henry (nitroaldol) reaction is an attractive synthetic tool in organic synthesis. The resulting products, chiral β-nitroalcohols, are important intermediates and can be further transformed into other useful derivatives such as carboxylic acids and amino alcohols [1,2]. In complicated synthetic ventures, the asymmetric Henry reaction will facilitate the combination of two molecular fragments, under mild conditions, with the formation of two asymmetric centers at the new carbon–carbon juncture [3]. Moreover, the reaction also turns out to be a key step in the preparation of some drugs [4,5]. Since Shibasaki and his co-workers reported the first chiral catalyst for the asymmetric Henry reaction between aldehydes and nitromethane in 1992, various catalytic systems for this reaction have been continuously developed [6–8]. These catalytic systems can be mainly divided into two categories: chiral complex based reactions and organocatalytic reactions. In the former system, chiral catalysts are mainly involved with rare earth–BINOL complexes [6], Cu–bis(oxazoline) (BOX) complexes [9–11], dinuclear Zn complexes [12], Zn salts–chiral amino alcohol [13], etc.; while in the latter, cinchona alkaloids [14], chiral thioureas [15] and guanidines are generally concerned [16]. In recent years, metal–salen complexes, especially the C 2-symmetric metallosalen compounds (Fig. 1 , ligand 1), have been proved to be useful catalysts for a wide range of organic reactions [17–19]. A group of modified (salen)CrIIICl complexes with bulky benzylic substituents in the 3,3′-position of the salicylidene moiety have been successfully applied for the asymmetric nitroaldol reaction with enantioselectivity usually over 80% up to 94% ee [19]. Copper(II) complexes of chiral secondary diamines derived from trans 1,2-diaminocyclohexane (DACH) (Fig. 1, ligand 2) were firstly used in an asymmetric nitroaldol reaction by Skarżewski and his coworkers, in which the product formation required 12mol% of the ligand and 10mol% of Cu(OAc)2 hydrate with good to excellent yields and enantioselectivity up to 94% [20]. After that, more diamine–copper complexes with bulky aromatic substituents [21–23] or aromatic macrocyclic units [24–27] were applied for asymmetric Henry reactions. Despite significant progress in this field, there are still some shortcomings for this kind of reaction such as rather complicated ligand structures, substrate specificity limitations. And what is more, there are few reports [23,28,29] available on asymmetric nitroaldol reaction where the product was synthesized on a gram-scale or more and catalyst could be readily recovered and reused with the almost maintained enantioselectivities. In our recent study, we have designed and developed a series of N-monoalkyl derivatives of DACH (Fig. 1, ligand 3) which can be expected as chiral ligands for asymmetric catalysis in addition to the preparation of Pt(II) complexes for antitumor agents screening [30]. Considering the rather good performance of secondary diamines in the asymmetric Henry reaction, we further designed and synthesized a class of new simple chiral DACH with both an alkyl group and an aromatic group, respectively, on each of two nitrogen atoms (Fig. 1, ligand 4), whose copper(II) complexes can be applied in the asymmetric Henry reaction of various aldehydes and nitroalkane. By using ligand 4, we would like to prove that those ligands including simple alkyl groups can also play a similar role like aromatic groups in the asymmetric Henry reaction with copper(II) ions in an excellent catalytic effect. And what is more, scale-up experiments were performed and the recyclability of the typical catalyst was verified. 2 Experimental 2.1 General All chemicals and solvents were of analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. (Boc)2O and (1R,2R)-DACH were obtained from a local chemical company. Infrared spectra were measured on KBr pellets on a Nicolet IR200 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400cm−1, and 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra with a Bruker 300MHz or 500MHz spectrometer were recorded. Mass spectra were measured on Agilent Accurate Mass 6224 TOF LC/MS system. 2.2 General procedure for the preparation of ligand 4 The synthetic process for ligand 3 has been described by our group previously [30], the general procedure in detail is as follows. The corresponding aldehyde or ketone (80mmol) was added to the stirring solution of mono-Boc protected (1R,2R)-DACH (40mmol) in MeOH (150mL). After the mixture was kept for 2h at room temperature, it was cooled in an ice-water bath, followed by adding NaBH4 (120mmol) slowly, and kept stirring overnight at 50°C. Then, water (10mL) was added to the above mixture, and white solids were obtained by concentrating the solution. After addition of 50mL water, the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (50mL×3). The combined organic extracts were washed by saturated NaCl solution and dried by anhydrous Na2SO4. By concentrating the solution in vacuo, the intermediate N 1-monoalkyl, N 2-Boc-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane was obtained. Then the intermediate was dissolved in absolute ether (75mL) and a solution of HCl/EtOAc (1mol/L, 50mL) was added slowly with stirring. The mixture was kept stirring for 12h at room temperature. The white solid was filtered off, washed with absolute ether and dried in vacuo with a yield of 42–84%. The product was obtained as dihydrochloride salt (3·2HCl). The relevant N-monoalkyl diamine (10mmol, prepared from the corresponding hydrochlorides 3·2HCl), was mixed with the corresponding aromatic aldehyde (20mmol) in MeOH (150mL). The mixture was kept stirring for 2h at room temperature, and then cooled in an ice-water bath, followed by adding NaBH4 (30mmol) slowly, and kept stirring 2h at 50°C. After that, 5mL of water was added to quench the reaction, then more water (30mL) was added and the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (30mL×3). The combined extract was washed by saturated NaCl solution and dried by anhydrous Na2SO4. By concentrating the solution in vacuo, the crude product was obtained. A solution of HCl/EtOAc (1mol/L, 20mL) was added slowly with stirring to the solution of the crude product in absolute ether (75mL), and the resulting white solid was filtered off, washed with ether and dried in vacuo to yield up to 90%. The product was also obtained as dihydrochloride salt (4·2HCl). The resulting suspension was gently heated for 30s and stirred for 1h to ensure completion of the complex formation. Then a solution of aldehyde (0.5mmol, 1equiv) in i-PrOH (0.3mL) was added at 25°C, the whole mixture was cooled to −20°C for 15min, treated with nitromethane (5.0mmol, 10equiv) via a syringe. After 5min, a solution of i-Pr2NEt (5.0mg, 7.70mol%) in i-PrOH (0.2mL) was added via a syringe. The mixture was stirred for 24h at −20°C. Purification by flash chromatography on silica gel (30g, n-hexane/AcOEt, 4:1, v/v) afforded the desired β-nitroalcohols. 2.4 HPLC conditions Enantiomeric excess was determined using HPLC on Chiralpak IC, Chiracel OD-H, or Chiralpak AD-H chiral columns. (3E)-1-Nitro-4-phenylbut-3-en-2-ol (5o): Chiracel OD-H, n-hexane/i-PrOH=85:15, 1.0mL/min, λ =206nm, t minor =25.5min, t major =28.2min. 3-Methyl-1-nitrobutan-2-ol (5p): Chiracel OD-H, n-hexane/i-PrOH=98:2, 0.6mL/min, λ =215nm, t minor =33.4min, t major =37.7min. 1-Nitrohexan-2-ol (5q): Chiralpak AD-H, n-hexane/i-PrOH=98:2, 0.8mL/min, λ =215nm, t minor =35.7min, t major =49.3min. 1-Cyclohexyl-2-nitroethanol (5r): Chiralpak AD-H, n-hexane/i-PrOH=90:10, 1.0mL/min, λ =225nm, t minor =8.8min, t major =9.4min. 3 Results and discussion In our preliminary experiments, 4-chlorobenzyl species has been chosen as a substituted group to get eight (1R,2R)-N 1-alkyl, N 2-arylmethylcyclohexane-1,2-diamines (AA-DACH) with a number of alkyl groups (ligands 4a-h), which were first examined in the Henry reaction between benzaldehyde and nitromethane (Table 1 , entries 1–8). An optimized method reported in the literature was adopted and developed to screen the ligands that can form efficient catalysts with Cu(II) ions in the Henry reaction [31]. The results showed that under these conditions the desired product (5a) was obtained in good yields with enantiomeric excess in most cases. High yields (up to 99%) and excellent enantioselectivities (≥91% ee) were achieved in the most reactions, and up to a 96% ee was obtained (Table 1, entry 7). Among these catalysts, the best one was 4g-Cu(OAc)2. These results indicated that AA-DACH are fairly good ligands to combine with copper(II) ions to function as effective catalysts in the enantioselective nitroaldol reaction, and their enantioselectivities are higher than those catalyzed by some chiral secondary diamine–Cu(II) complexes [for example, complex of copper acetate and N,N′-di(4-chlorobenzyl)-(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane] [21–23]. It is noticed that the size of the alkyl chain does not have a significant effect on the yield and the ee of the product. Five (1R,2R)-N 1-(4-methylpentan-2-yl), N 2-arylmethylcyclohexane-1,2-diamines were examined in the Henry reaction of benzaldehyde and nitromethane (Table 2 , entries 1–5). High yields (up to 99%) and excellent enantioselectivities (88–94% ee) were achieved in the reaction. But these results are lower than that of 4g-Cu(OAc)2 (96% ee). Thus, 4-chlorobenzyl moiety is believed as an ideal substituted group. In order to explore the scope of the reaction with such a catalyst, we applied the optimal catalyst 4g-Cu(OAc)2 to the Henry reactions between various aldehydes and nitromethane, respectively (Table 3 , aromatic aldehydes: entries 1–14, aliphatic aldehydes: entries 15–17). A variety of aromatic aldehydes provided the corresponding β-nitroalcohols with good to high yields (up to 99%) and enantioselectivities ranging from 75% to 94%. It is noted that the electronic and steric properties of the ring substituent of the aromatic aldehyde have a slight influence on the enantioselectivity of the resulting products. On the other hand, with aliphatic aldehydes, the corresponding β-nitroalcohols were obtained with relatively low yields (26–78%) in spite of high enantioselectivities (≥90%). It was noted that reaction activity of the aliphatic aldehyde is relatively low, but the enantioselectivity of products is not affected. Besides, catalysts 4a-Cu(OAc)2, 4d-Cu(OAc)2, and 4h-Cu(OAc)2 were also applied to study the Henry reactions of various aromatic aldehydes with nitromethane (Table 3, entries 18–26). The corresponding β-nitroalcohols were obtained with good to high yields (up to 99%) and enantioselectivities ranging from 71% to 94%. These results demonstrated that AA-DACH can be applied in the Henry reaction with various aromatic aldehydes. Upon scaling up to gram quantities (5mmol), the desired product 5a was obtained in good yield (96%) with excellent selectivity (94% ee) by using 12mol% of 4g (10mL i-PrOH), 10mol% of Cu(OAc)2·H2O (Scheme 1 ). Furthermore, when the amount of reactants (benzaldehyde) is a gram scale (10mmol, 1.06g), high yield (91%) and excellent enantioselectivity (93% ee) were still achieved in the reaction. So 4g-Cu(OAc)2 could be used as a suitable catalyst to prepare large amount of β-nitroalcohol with high ee value. To demonstrate the recyclability of 4g-Cu(OAc)2, experiments were carried out by using benzaldehyde with nitromethane (Table 4 ). After completion of the reaction the product was obtained by flash chromatography on silica gel (30g, n-hexane/AcOEt, 4:1, v/v) and then the recovered catalyst was obtained (60g, MeOH). After removing MeOH by rotary evaporation, the recovered catalyst was dried in vacuum (recovery rate: about 70%), which was used for the subsequent catalytic runs. The recovered catalyst worked well up to three catalytic runs with marginal loss in yield and enantioselectivity of the product was retained (yield: 91%, ee: 90%). Based on the generally accepted model proposed by Evans et al. [10] and Kodama et al. [27], we suggested a possible catalytic transition state for our asymmetric Henry reactions (Fig. 2 ). The copper(II) ion in an octahedral geometry has four strong coordination sites at the equatorial positions and two weak coordination sites at the apical positions due to the Jahn–Teller effect. Two nitrogen atoms of ligand 4g occupy two neighboring coordination sites. Both the aldehyde and nitromethane are efficiently activated by coordination to the equatorial and the apical position of the metal atom, respectively. To reduce the spatial hindrance, the aromatic group connecting to the cyclohexyldiamine skeleton via a flexible methylene group is below the coordination plane, while the bulky alkyl moiety on the other side. Thus, the aldehyde and nitroalkane are obliged to coordinate with the metal ion in the fixed positions to achieve the less crowded space. 4 Conclusion A number of simple chiral diamines AA-DACH (ligand 4) have been synthesized and applied to form the corresponding copper(II) complexes as catalysts in asymmetric Henry reaction of aldehyde and nitromethane. 4g-Cu(OAc)2 was found as an efficient catalyst in the asymmetric Henry reaction between various aldehydes and nitromethane, and the resulting β-nitroalcohols were obtained with high chemical yields (up to 99%) and high enantiomeric excess (up to 96%). Our results show that 4g-Cu(OAc)2 could be readily recovered and reused in the asymmetric Henry reaction to obtain large amounts of β-nitroalcohol with high enantioselectivity. In addition, ligand 4 may be applied to other asymmetric reactions. Reaction conditions such as reaction time, temperatures, bases, solvents, metal salts and so on were examined in the Henry reaction of benzaldehyde and nitromethane in our preliminary experiments. By considering the yield and the enantioselectivity of products, the optimization of reaction conditions was obtained as follows: reactions were performed on a 0.5mmol scale, 12mol% of ligand, 10mol% of Cu(OAc)2·H2O, 10equiv of CH3NO2 and 7.7mol% of i-Pr2NEt in i-PrOH at −20°C for 24h. coredata.dc:description: A class of (1R,2R)-N 1-alkyl, N 2-(4-chlorobenzyl)cyclohexane-1,2-diamines (4) were designed and synthesized. They were used to form the corresponding copper(II) complexes, 4-Cu(OAc)2, as chiral catalysts in the asymmetric Henry reaction of benzaldehyde and nitromethane, in which the desired product was obtained with a good yield (up to 99%) and up to 96% ee. The optimized catalyst, 4g-Cu(OAc)2, was also found efficient in the asymmetric Henry reaction between different aldehydes (aromatic aldehydes or aliphatic aldehydes) and nitromethane. Upon scaling up to gram quantities, the β-nitroalcohol was obtained in good yield (91%) with excellent selectivities (93% ee). The recycled catalyst, 4g-Cu(OAc)2, worked well up to three catalytic runs with marginal loss in yield and the enantioselectivity of the product was retained. It is believed that this procedure provides an opportunity to facilely synthesize large amounts of enantiomerically enriched β-nitroalcohol. A possible catalytic transition state for the asymmetric Henry reactions with our catalyst was suggested.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient and recyclable catalysts based on simple chiral N 1-alkyl, N 2-arylmethyl diamines in the Cu-catalyzed asymmetric Henry reactions
